description: From Middle English daschen, dassen, from Danish daske (“to slap, strike”), related to Swedish daska (“to smack, slap, spank”), of obscure origin. Compare German tatschen (“to grope, paw”), Old English dwǣsċan (“to quell, put out, destroy, extinguish”). See also adwesch, dush.

definitionGroups.group: (typography) Any of the following symbols: ‒ (figure dash), – (en dash), — (em dash), or ― (horizontal bar).

entries.meaning: (by extension) The longer of the two symbols of Morse code.

examples: When the feds came they did the dash.

They say that I’m way too cold, I never get tired of rappinMy word is bang where I come fromWatch be one work is magicDo it and dash itSmile on MATNo way this peng one actingWho got whacked and who got slappedAnd who got spared by dashes

entries.meaning: A small quantity of a liquid substance etc.; less than 1/8 of a teaspoon.
examples: Add a dash of vinegar.
There is a dash of craziness in his personality.
Aren't we full of dash this morning?
The dash clock said 2:38 when […]  I turned off a dirt road […] .

entries.meaning: (Nigeria, Ghana, Liberia) A bribe or gratuity; a gift.
examples: The traditional practice of offering gifts or "dash" to chiefs has often been misinterpreted by scholars to provide a cultural explanation for the pervasive incidence of bribery and corruption in modern Africa.

entries.meaning: (dated, euphemistic) A stand-in for a censored word, like "Devil" or "damn". (Compare deuce.)
examples: Sir Thomas looks as if to ask what the dash is that to you! but wanting still to go to India again, and knowing how strong the Newcomes are in Leadenhall Street, he thinks it necessary to be civil to the young cub, and swallows his pride once more into his waistband.
Comment: Some editions leave this passage out. Of those that include it, some change the 'you!' to 'you?'.

entries.meaning: (Internet, informal) The dashboard of a Tumblr user.
examples: -i hope you find at least one thing on your dash that will make you laugh today.

verbs.description: dash (third-person singular simple present dashes, present participle dashing, simple past and past participle dashed)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To run quickly or for a short distance.
examples: He dashed across the field.
I have to dash now. See you soon.
He dashed the bottle against the bar and turned about to fight.
The man was dashed from the vehicle during the accident.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, sometimes figurative) To sprinkle; to splatter.
(transitive, dated) To mix, reduce, or adulterate, by throwing in something of an inferior quality.
examples: to dash wine with water

entries.meaning: (transitive, of hopes or dreams) To ruin; to destroy.
examples: Her hopes were dashed when she saw the damage.
Her thoughts were dashed to melancholy.

entries.meaning: (transitive, usually with down or off) To complete hastily.
examples: He dashed down his eggs.
She dashed off her homework.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To draw or write quickly; jot.
examples: Going out the door, he grabbed a windbreaker and dashed a note to his father and left it on the entry table.
Dash his impudence! Who is that scoundrel?
